---
title: "In class Exercise 2 - Beyond Plotting Fundamentals"
---




Plotting of exam_data dataset, below:


::: {.cell}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
# A tibble: 6 Ã— 7
  ID         CLASS GENDER RACE    ENGLISH MATHS SCIENCE
  <chr>      <chr> <chr>  <chr>     <dbl> <dbl>   <dbl>
1 Student321 3I    Male   Malay        21     9      15
2 Student305 3I    Female Malay        24    22      16
3 Student289 3H    Male   Chinese      26    16      16
4 Student227 3F    Male   Chinese      27    77      31
5 Student318 3I    Male   Malay        27    11      25
6 Student306 3I    Female Malay        31    16      16
```
:::
:::


1.  Scatterplot of Maths against English with hover effects. Colours represent class


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
p1 <- plot_ly(data = exam_data, 
             x = ~MATHS, 
             y = ~ENGLISH,
        color=~CLASS,
        coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                        ylim=c(0,100)))
```
:::


2.  Scatterplot of Maths against Science with hover effects. Colours represent class.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
p2 <- plot_ly(data = exam_data, 
             x = ~MATHS, 
             y = ~SCIENCE,
        color=~CLASS,
        coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                        ylim=c(0,100)))
```
:::


3.  Bringing it all together (side by side), with an economist theme.\
    Also split the table into 4 quadrants for better visualisation and analysis.
